questions.text: During an outbreak investigation in Kerala, India, several patients presented with fever and encephalitis. The outbreak is linked to contact with infected pigs, and fruit bats are abundant in the area. Laboratory analysis of patient samples reveals a paramyxovirus. The mortality rate is approximately 70%. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Key Facts (NIPAH)
  • N - Nervous system affected
  • I - Infection mortality 60-70%
  • P - Pigs are amplifiers
  • A - Animal-to-human transmission
  • H - History of the outbreak in Kerala 2018

Transmission Cycle
  • Vector: Fruit bats (natural reservoir)
  • Intermediate host: Pigs (amplifiers)
  • Human infection: Through contaminated food/water
  • Patient secretions can spread disease

Clinical Features
  • Encephalitis (primary manifestation)
  • Fever
  • High mortality rate (60-70%)
  • Neurological symptoms

Diagnosis
  • RT-PCR is the primary diagnostic test
  • Sample: CSF or brain tissue
  • Serology can be supportive

Prevention
  • Avoid contact with infected animals
  • Proper handling of infected pig carcasses
  • Avoid consuming contaminated fruits
  • Protection from fruit bat secretions

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and spots on the buccal mucosa as shown below after a recent family trip. The mother reports no vaccinations. Which statement best describes the incubation period and transmission mode of the suspected illness?

options.label: C
options.text: Incubation period: 3-5 days; contaminated surfaces only

options.label: D
options.text: Incubation period: 7-8 days; direct skin contact

questions.correct_answer: B. Incubation period: 10-14 days; respiratory droplets

questions.text: A 75-year-old female presents to the clinic with symptoms of high fever, chills, cough, body aches, and fatigue. She has a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease. She reports she has never received an influenza vaccine. The patient is worried about her symptoms and potential complications. Which of the following statements about influenza vaccination is most appropriate for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: She should receive the live attenuated influenza vaccine (LAIV) because it is more effective for elderly individuals.

options.label: B
options.text: She should avoid the influenza vaccine because of her chronic kidney disease.

options.label: C
options.text: She should receive the high-dose inactivated influenza vaccine (HD-IIV) to provide better protection.

options.label: D
options.text: Influenza vaccination is not recommended for individuals above 65 years old.

questions.correct_answer: C. She should receive the high-dose inactivated influenza vaccine (HD-IIV) to provide better protection.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with acute onset of barking cough, hoarseness, and mild respiratory distress that worsens at night. Physical examination reveals inspiratory stridor but normal lung fields. The child attends preschool where several other children have similar symptoms. The illness started with mild upper respiratory symptoms 2 days ago. No other significant clinical findings are seen. Which of the following viruses is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Parainfluenza Virus

Clinical Features
  • Croup (Types 1 and 2)
  • Lower respiratory disease (Type 3)
  • Mild respiratory illness (Type 4)
  • Adults: mild URI, hoarseness
  • Rarely causes parotitis

Epidemiology
  • Type 3: Common in the first year of life
  • Types 1 & 2: Preschool children
  • First infections more serious
  • 50% of infants become seropositive by 12 months

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • Specimen: Throat/nasal swabs
  • Virus isolation: Monkey kidney cells
  • Serology: Paired sera samples
  • PCR: Most rapid and sensitive

Transmission
  • Air/respiratory droplets
  • Through fingers
  • Nosocomial spread uncommon
  • No vaccine available

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with progressive respiratory distress, cough, and rhinorrhea during winter. The child attends daycare, and several other infants there have similar symptoms. Physical examination reveals tachypnea, wheezing, and bilateral crackles. Further testing is done, and the patient is diagnosed with Respiratory Syncytial Virus. Which of the following statements regarding RSV infection in this case is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: PCR testing is insensitiv,e but viral culture is the gold standard

options.label: B
options.text: Maternal antibodies provide complete protection at this age

options.label: C
options.text: The peak incidence occurs at 2-3 months of age with increased hospitalization risk

options.label: D
options.text: Live-attenuated vaccine is recommended for prevention

questions.correct_answer: C. The peak incidence occurs at 2-3 months of age with increased hospitalization risk
questions.explanation:
Respiratory Syncytial Virus

Epidemiology
  • Global distribution
  • Winter epidemics in temperate regions
  • Peak age: 2-3 months
  • Common in daycares, nurseries
  • Incubation period: 4-6 days

Transmission
  • Close Contact
  • Contaminated fingers and fomites
  • Respiratory droplets
  • Virus shedding: 1-3 weeks

Clinical Features
  •  Most infections symptomatic
  •  Range from mild to severe respiratory illness
  •  25-40% develop lower respiratory involvement
  •  Hospitalization rate: ~1%
  • Recovery usually in 1-2 weeks

Diagnosis
  •  Specimen: Nasopharyngeal swabs
  •  PCR: Sensitive and rapid(Option A)
  •  Immunofluorescence tests
  •  Serology: Paired samples for antibody titers

Treatment
  •  Primarily supportive care
  •  Ribavirin for severe cases
  •  Palivizumab is a respiratory syncytial virus f protein monoclonal antibody and is used in severe cases in children.
  •  No effective vaccine available(Option D)

Risk Factors
  •  Age < 6 months, Since maternal antibodies provide only partial protection and decline by 2-3 months (Option B)
  •  Prematurity
  •  Immunodeficiency
  •  Cardiac defects

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with bilateral painful swelling in the region of his parotid glands that began 2 days ago. His mother notes that the pain worsens when he drinks orange juice. He had a fever of 101.2°F (38.4°C) before the swelling appeared. The patient's vaccination status is unknown. During examination, bilateral parotid enlargement is noted. Which of the following is the most specific diagnostic test to confirm the suspected infection in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis Methods

RT-PCR
  • Buccal swab
  • Most specific test
  • Collect within first 3 days

Antigen
  • ELISA method
  • Used for rapid screening

Clinical Features
  • Bilateral parotitis
  • Pain increases with citrus juices
  • Fever and malaise

Culture

Only in cell lines

Vaccine Details- MMR

Recommended Strain- Mumps

Jeryl Lynn Strain

Measles Strain

Edmonston/Zagreb

Rubella Strain

RA 27/3

Type

MMR-V (with varicella)

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with a 3-day history of fever, headache, and bilateral parotid gland swelling. He reports no recent vaccinations. Physical examination reveals painful, swollen parotid glands and lab tests show elevated serum amylase. Which complication is most likely to develop if the condition progresses?
questions.explanation:
Respiratory Route

Spread occurs through respiratory droplets, saliva, and fomites contaminated by the virus.

Incubation Period

About 19 days, with a range from 7 to 23 days.

Infectivity

Patients are contagious from 1 week before symptoms to 1 week after.

The peak infective period is 1–2 days before symptoms begin.

Source

Both clinical and subclinical cases are infectious, with subclinical cases (30–40% of infections) helping sustain transmission.

Reservoir

Humans are the only known reservoir, with no carrier state identified.

Parotitis

The most common specific feature, presenting in 70–90% of cases, is usually bilateral parotid swelling.

Orchitis/Epididymo-orchitis

Seen in 15–30% of postpubertal males, usually unilateral; infertility is rare due to unilateral involvement.

Aseptic Meningitis

Occurs in less than 10% of cases, typically self-limiting, but can cause permanent deafness if cranial nerves are affected.

Oophoritis

Found in about 5% of infected women.

Pancreatitis

Affects approximately 4% of cases, leading to diabetes in rare cases.

Atypical Presentation

Some patients may present with aseptic meningitis without parotitis (in 10% of cases).

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant presents with high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, rash over the buccal mucosa, and a spreading maculopapular rash. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Educate on supportive care and schedule the vaccine at 12 months

questions.text: A 3-year-old unvaccinated child presents with high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash that began on the face and has spread to the trunk and limbs. Oral examination reveals small, white lesions on the buccal mucosa. Which complication is most likely to develop in the acute phase of this illness?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Duration

Symptoms

Incubation Period

10 days (up to 21 days)

Asymptomatic phase; the virus multiplies in the respiratory tract, followed by primary and secondary viremia.

Prodromal Stage

4 days
  • Fever (day 10),
  • Koplik’s spots (day 12),
  • non-specific symptoms (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis).

Eruptive Stage

4 days post fever

The maculopapular rash appears first behind the ears, then spreads to the face, trunk, and limbs, fading in the same order.

Post-measles Stage

Variable

Characterized by weight loss, weakness, and a risk of progressing to chronic conditions.

questions.text: A patient comes to the clinic with symptoms of a viral infection. The physician is reviewing potential viruses based on their classification into myxovirus families. Which of the following viruses is NOT a member of the Paramyxoviridae family?
questions.explanation:
Properties

Orthomyxoviridae

Paramyxoviridae

Size

80-120 nm

100-300 nm

Shape

Spherical; Rarely filamentous

Pleomorphic

Nucleic acid

Negative sense ssRNA, Segmented; eight pieces

Negative sense ssRNA Unsegmented; single piece

Genetic recombination

Seen

Not seen

Antigenic variation

Seen

Not seen

Site for RNA Replication

Nucleus

Cytoplasm

Important human pathogens

Influenza virus

Parainfluenza virus, Mumps virus Respiratory syncytial virus Measles virus, Metapneumovirus

Antigens: Hemagglutinin (HA) and Neuraminidase (NA)

Both HA and NA spikes are present, So hemagglutination is reversible (Elution seen)

HA spike present in Parainfluenza, Mumps, Measles,

NA spike present in Parainfluenza, Mumps

Inclusion body: Intracytoplasmic (only for measles, it is both intracytoplasmic and intranuclear)

questions.text: A 30-year-old healthcare worker presents with sudden onset fever, chills, sore throat, and muscle aches. She reports exposure to multiple patients with similar symptoms. The physician suspects influenza and requests a diagnostic test for confirmation. A nasopharyngeal swab is collected, and a Hemagglutination Inhibition (HI) test is performed. The results show a significant increase in antibody titers in the second sample compared to the first sample, taken 10 days apart. Which of the following best explains the findings and indicates a confirmed diagnosis of influenza?

options.label: A
options.text: The HI test shows no change in antibody titers between the first and second samples.

options.label: B
options.text: The HI test shows a fourfold increase in antibody titers between the first and second samples.

options.label: C
options.text: The HI test shows a twofold decrease in antibody titers between the first and second samples.

options.label: D
options.text: The HI test shows a single positive result with no subsequent titer testing.

questions.correct_answer: B. The HI test shows a fourfold increase in antibody titers between the first and second samples.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with COPD presents with high fever, chills, myalgia, and dry cough, which started suddenly. Influenza A is confirmed by a rapid test. He missed his annual influenza vaccine this year. What is the best next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Prescribe supportive care only, as antivirals are not effective beyond 48 hours.

options.label: D
options.text: Recommend the influenza vaccine now to prevent the progression of symptoms

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the clinic with flu-like symptoms during the winter months. The physician discusses the different types of influenza viruses with the patient, emphasizing their characteristics and impacts on public health. Which of the following statements about influenza viruses discussed by the physician is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: Influenza A has 18 HA and 11 NA subtypes.

options.label: B
options.text: Influenza B is classified into subtypes based on its HA and NA proteins.

options.label: C
options.text: Influenza A is known to cause both seasonal epidemics and pandemics.

options.label: D
options.text: Influenza C rarely causes severe illness in humans and has a low public health impact.

questions.correct_answer: B. Influenza B is classified into subtypes based on its HA and NA proteins.

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes antigenic drift and antigenic shift in influenza viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: Drift causes pandemics; shift causes minor epidemics.

options.label: B
options.text: Drift involves minor mutations; shift involves genetic reassortment.

options.label: C
options.text: Shift occurs in Influenza A and B; drift occurs only in Influenza A.

options.label: D
options.text: Drift produces a new strain; shift evades immune recognition.

questions.correct_answer: B. Drift involves minor mutations; shift involves genetic reassortment.
questions.explanation:
Antigenic Drift

Antigenic Shift
  • Minor change due to point mutations in HA/NA genes, altering amino acid sequences and helping the virus partially evade immune recognition. (Option D)
  • Requires two or more mutations for significant impact.
  • Occurs in both influenza A and B viruses. (Option C)
  • Leads to outbreaks and minor epidemics, occurring every 2–3 years. (Option A)
  • An abrupt, major change in HA/NA genes due to genetic reassortment between influenza viruses infecting the same host.
  • Produces a new virus strain, making prior antibodies ineffective. (Option D)
  • Occurs only in influenza A virus. (Option C)
  • Causes pandemics and major epidemics, with shifts happening every 10–20 years (e.g., the H1N1 pandemic of 2009). (Option A)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man visits the emergency department with complaints of high fever, severe headache, and muscle aches that started 24 hours ago. He mentions he has been feeling increasingly fatigued and has developed a dry cough. Which of the following statements about the virus causing his symptoms is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Amantadine acts against both A and B strains of the virus whereas Oseltamivir acts against strain A only.

options.label: B
options.text: The incubation period for the virus is 7 to 14 days.

options.label: C
options.text: The immune response mainly involves antibodies against the hemagglutinin protein.

options.label: D
options.text: Once infected, individuals develop lifelong immunity against all strains of the virus.

questions.correct_answer: C. The immune response mainly involves antibodies against the hemagglutinin protein.

questions.text: Match each structure of the Orthomyxovirus (Influenza Virus) with its corresponding function. 1. Hemagglutinin (HA) A) Forms ion channels in the envelope 2. Neuraminidase (NA) B) Responsible for RNA transcription and replication 3. Polymerase proteins (PB1, PB2, PA) C) Aids in viral release and prevents virion aggregation 4. Nucleoprotein D) Binds sialic acid receptors for viral entry 5. Matrix protein - M1 E) Forms a shell beneath the envelope 6. Matrix protein - M2 F) Forms a ribonucleoprotein complex with viral RNA

A medical student is studying viral classifications and comes across various RNA virus families. The student needs to identify misconceptions regarding the properties of these viruses. Which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: Coronaviridae and Flaviviridae are examples of positive-sense RNA viruses.

options.label: B
options.text: Bunyavirus has segmented RNA with 7 segments.

options.label: C
options.text: Orthomyxovirus contains segmented RNA with 7-8 segments.

options.label: D
options.text: Rhabdovirus and Myxovirus are examples of negative-sense RNA viruses.

questions.correct_answer: B. Bunyavirus has segmented RNA with 7 segments.
questions.explanation:
Positive sense

Negative sense
  • Picornaviridae
  • Flaviviridae
  • Togaviridae
  • Hepeviridae
  • Coronaviridae (Option A ruled out)
  • M: Myxovirus
  • R: Rhabdovirus (Option D ruled out)
  • F: Filovirus
  • A: Arenavirus
  • B: Bunyavirus
